Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Testing the Intrinsic Benefit Model of Cultural Signaling

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-1404371
Joseph Galaskiewicz
Sosuke Okada
University of Arizona


In many social interactions, it is important to determine qualities of others, such as competence, loyalty, or trustworthiness. Signaling theory focuses on these situations. The senders possess an internal characteristic which they aware of, but is unobservable to others. There is a conflict of interest between the sender and the receiver, as the sender benefits from being perceived in a better light, whereas the receiver wants to accurately determine the sender's internal characteristic. Under this condition, a signal will be reliable only when the cost of producing the signal is lower for those with higher quality than for those with lower quality. The co-PI proposes the model of cultural signaling where the sender can enjoy intrinsic benefits from engaging in a cultural act. The intrinsic benefit reduces the net cost of practicing the cultural act for the sender, which will result in the inverse association between quality and signaling cost. For example, if someone is more committed to a social cause, s/he can gain more intrinsic benefit (feeling good, for example) from contributing to the cause. This intrinsic benefit can make up for the actual cost of the contribution; therefore the contribution is effectively less expensive for those who are more committed to it. This way, cultural acts can function as signals of desirable internal qualities.

The intrinsic benefit model makes the following predictions. First, senders are more willing to pay higher cost to perform a cultural act when they have a high level of the corresponding characteristic. Second, a cultural act will be perceived as a signal of intrinsic quality when it appears to be costly for the sender to perform the cultural act, and there are no salient extrinsic benefits from signaling that are potentially motivating the cultural act. Third, the visibility of a cultural act should affect how well the cultural act can function as a signal. For the sender, high visibility of a cultural act can make it more attractive, but for the receiver, high visibility can make the sender's extrinsic motivation more salient. The project will conduct three experiments to test the predictions. The first two experiments will focus on purchase of an electronic vehicle as the signal of environmental commitment. The third experiment will focus on charitable giving as a signal of social preference.

Broader Impacts

The main advantage of the intrinsic benefit model is that it provides a general, easy-to-use framework which will allow applying signaling theory across diverse phenomena of sociological interest while using an assumption which is widely accepted among laypersons. The proposal argues that applications in organizational studies (in particular, the interactions between organizations and their audience), intragroup dynamics (both cooperation and competition), and research on cultural capital can potentially greatly benefit from the intrinsic benefit model. This model can provide a parsimonious rational-choice based explanation for many behaviors that are seemingly irrational or culturally determined. In addition, it can also help develop techniques for promoting socially beneficial behaviors through manipulating signaling benefits. For example, the investigators argue that many seemingly maladaptive behaviors are motivated by the need for signaling -- not only can our research shed new insight into such behaviors, but it can also help reduce such behaviors by reducing signaling benefits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was aimed to develop and test the intrinsic benefit model of signaling theory. The signaling theory, originally developed in economics and evolutionary biology, deals with situations with asymmetrical information where the sender has an internal characteristic which is invisible to others. The receiver wants to correctly determine the sender’s quality, and the sender wants to convince the receiver that s/he is of high quality. In its most well-known form, the signaling theory shows that a signal is reliable if the cost of producing a signal is cheaper for the sender of high quality than for the sender of low quality. This project proposes that it is possible to establish the cost-quality association if the intrinsic benefit the sender can obtain from an act (that is being used as a signal) is perceived to be associated with his/her quality. For example, those who are committed to a political cause would obtain more intrinsic benefit from participating in a demonstration. This modification can allow for applying the signaling theory to a much wider range of social phenomena than it was previously possible, especially about signaling of intangible qualities such as loyalty, commitment, or sophistication.

Because the intrinsic benefit model is based on the perceived association between an internal characteristic and an intrinsic benefit, the factors which can break the perceived association can potentially reduce the effectiveness of the signal. This project focused on the visibility as the factor which can affect the dynamics of signaling within the intrinsic benefit model. We proposed that increased visibility can weaken the perceived association between the internal characteristic and the intrinsic benefit obtained from an act. A high visibility signal can be perceived as a sign that the sender is driven by the motivation to improve his/her image, instead of being motivated by intrinsic benefit. At the same time, high visibility signal, by its nature, can potentially reach broader audience – creating a dilemma for the sender.

This project conducted four experiments – three online experiments and one laboratory experiment – centered around the use of prosocial behaviors as the signals. The online experiments used a vignette design, which asks the subjects to describe their likely behavior based on varying vignettes. We tested how the purchase of electronic vehicles (EV) function as the signal of pro-environment attitude, and the experiment was conducted on subjects recruited through Amazon Mechanical Turk. The experiment#1 tested how the receivers of a signal interpret the signal in the hypothetical situations. The results supported the predictions: the actor who produced high-cost signal (buying a more expensive EV) is perceived as having more pro-environment attitude, whereas the actor who produced high visibility signal (buying an EV with distinctive appearance) is perceived as having less pro-environmental attitude. The latter effect was mediated by the perceived signaling motive of the hypothetical actor – the subjects thought that the hypothetical actor who produced high visibility signal was more likely to be motivated to improve their image to others, thus they tended to interpret the actor as having less pro-environmental attitudes. The experiment#2 and #3 tested how the senders of the signal would behave in the hypothetical situations. We failed to obtain consistent results, except that those with more pro-environmental attitude were willing to pay more for EVs.

The experiment#4 was conducted in a laboratory on university students, and it studied how donations are used as a signal of trustworthiness.  To measure trust and trustworthiness, the trust game was used – in a trust game, the first actor has to decide whether or not to give an endowment to the second. The experimenter multiplies the endowment, and the second actor then decides on how to split the sum. Thus, the first actor would have to determine if the second actor is trustworthy or not, and the second actor would wish to appear trustworthy to the first actor. In this experiment, subjects were asked to decide on making a donation in the beginning of the experiment. The experiment was designed so that in one treatment condition, subjects knew they would be playing trust game afterward (with their donation information visible) before deciding on donation, whereas in another treatment condition, the subjects did not know they would be playing trust game after deciding on donation.  Contrary to the previous research which tested whether donations are used as the signal of trustworthiness, the subjects in this experiment did not treat donation as the signal of trustworthiness, although donators were more trustworthy than non-donators. Similarly, there is no evidence that the knowledge of subsequent trust games increased the likelihood of donations. However, the finding indicates that the awareness of the possibility that the donations were made for image motive may have reduced the level of transfer in the trust game, regardless of the actual donation made by their partner.
